Elevation of Privilege.description: An attacker has compromised a key technology supplier.
An attacker can access the cloud service which manages your devices.
An attacker can escape from a container or other sandbox.
An attacker can force data through different validation paths which give different results.
An attacker could take advantage of permissions you set, but don't use.
An attacker can provide a pointer across a trust boundary, rather than data which can be validated.
An attacker can enter data that is checked while still under their control and used later on the other side of a trust boundary.
There's no reasonable way for a caller to figure out what validation of tainted data you perform before passing it to them.
There's no reasonable way for a caller to figure out what security assumptions you make.
An attacker can reflect input back to a user, like cross site scripting.
You include user-generated content within your page, possibly including the content of random URLs.
An attacker can inject a command that the system will run at a higher privilege level.
An attacker exploits an outdated administrative tool that still has default credentials to gain unauthorized access to system settings.
A rogue employee escalates their access by exploiting weak session management to hijack a session of a higher-privileged user.
An attacker leverages a SQL injection vulnerability to alter user role permissions in a database, granting themselves admin rights.
Through phishing, an attacker convinces a user to install a malicious application that exploits operating system vulnerabilities to gain root access.
An attacker bypasses two-factor authentication using a stolen mobile device and intercepts SMS codes to access a protected network.
An attacker modifies firmware on internet-connected devices to bypass security controls and monitor network traffic.
Using a zero-day vulnerability, an attacker escalates privileges within an application to execute arbitrary code on the server.
An attacker exploits improper input validation in an IoT device to gain control over device operations and access restricted areas.
A malicious script embedded in a web advertisement exploits browser vulnerabilities to elevate privileges and steal sensitive cookies.
An attacker injects malicious code into a shared software library used by multiple applications, gaining elevated privileges across all applications using the library.
